keyTakeAways: A former New York state prison guard, David Kingsley, was found guilty of murder and first-degree manslaughter in the beating death of inmate Robert Brooks.
Two other guards, Mathew Galliher and Nicholas Kieffer, were acquitted of murder charges despite being charged with multiple offenses, including gang assault and false filing.
The body-camera footage, though silent, showed guards aggressively beating Brooks and appeared to show a lack of concern, which became central to the prosecution's case.
Brooks sustained serious injuries including a broken nose, black eye, and internal organ damage, with blood leaking into his lungs and stomach.
All guards were accused of acting as a gang with depraved indifference to human life, per prosecutor William Fitzpatrick.
The case is part of a larger pattern of misconduct, with a similar case involving the death of Messiah Nantwi at Mid-State Correctional Facility under the same special prosecutor.
William Fitzpatrick, acting as a special prosecutor after Letitia James recused herself, has taken over multiple cases involving prison guard abuse.
Six of 10 guards indicted initially were charged with murder, with five pleading guilty to manslaughter and one to a misdemeanor related to evidence tampering.
Three more guards have agreed to plead guilty to reduced charges and are cooperating with prosecutors.
The verdict reflects public outrage and heightened scrutiny of prison guard conduct and accountability.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A former New York prison guard, David Kingsley, was found guilty of murder and first-degree manslaughter in the fatal beating of inmate Robert Brooks, who was attacked multiple times upon arrival at Marcy Correctional Facility on December 9, 2024. The incident, captured on silent body-camera footage showing guards punching, stomping, and lifting Brooks by the neck, sparked public outrage and led to a jury conviction of Kingsley, while Mathew Galliher and Nicholas Kieffer were acquitted of murder charges despite being involved in the assault. The prosecution argued that all guards acted as a gang with a depraved indifference to human life. The case is part of a broader pattern of prison misconduct, with a similar incident involving Messiah Nantwi at Mid-State Correctional Facility under the same prosecutor, William Fitzpatrick, who took over after Attorney General Letitia James recused herself due to conflicts of interest. Several other guards have pleaded guilty to reduced charges or are on trial, highlighting ongoing legal and public scrutiny of prison guard conduct and systemic accountability.
title: Former New York state prison guard found guilty in death of inmate beaten, 2 others acquitted
